summary: This research investigates the role of Replication Protein A (RPA) in DNA maintenance, revealing its ability to bind and diffuse along single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) and disrupt double-stranded DNA (duplex DNA). The study demonstrates that the yeast protein Pif1 can utilize its ATP-dependent translocase activity to move human RPA along ssDNA, effectively pushing it into duplex DNA and causing stable disruptions. These findings highlight the dynamic nature of RPA and elucidate a mechanism for directional DNA unwinding, emphasizing the separate yet complementary roles of RPA and Pif1 in helicase activity.
